unnormalised: The monsoon season in Mumbai brought with it the usual deluge of chai cravings and Bollywood dance numbers on TV. But this year, it brought something else too – a nasty bout of dengue fever that swept through my building, affecting nearly 15 residents. It all started with a mild fever in my neighbour, Mrs. Sharma, around 10/07/2024. She initially dismissed it as just a monsoon cold, popping a Crocin and carrying on with her daily routine of managing her household and chasing after her mischievous grandson.
normalised: The monsoon season in Mumbai brought with it the usual deluge of chai cravings and Bollywood dance numbers on T-V. But this year, it brought something else too – a nasty bout of dengue fever that swept through my building, affecting nearly fifteen residents. It all started with a mild fever in my neighbour, Mrs. Sharma, around tenth July two thousand and twenty four. She initially dismissed it as just a monsoon cold, popping a Crocin and carrying on with her daily routine of managing her household and chasing after her mischievous grandson.

unnormalised: However, by 12/07/2024, her condition worsened. The fever spiked to 102°F, accompanied by excruciating joint pain and a relentless headache. Her family doctor, Dr. Patil, suspected dengue and advised a blood test immediately. The reports confirmed the dreaded diagnosis: Dengue NS1 antigen positive. Dr. Patil prescribed bed rest, plenty of fluids, and Paracetamol 650mg for fever relief. He also stressed the importance of mosquito control to prevent further spread.
normalised: However, by twelfth July two thousand and twenty four, her condition worsened. The fever spiked to one hundred and two degree Fahrenheit, accompanied by excruciating joint pain and a relentless headache. Her family doctor, Dr. Patil, suspected dengue and advised a blood test immediately. The reports confirmed the dreaded diagnosis: Dengue N-S-one antigen positive. Dr. Patil prescribed bed rest, plenty of fluids, and Paracetamol six hundred and fifty milligram for fever relief. He also stressed the importance of mosquito control to prevent further spread.

unnormalised: News of Mrs. Sharma’s illness spread like wildfire throughout our close-knit community. Soon after, my own son, Rohan, started exhibiting similar symptoms on 15/07/2024. A quick trip to the local clinic and another agonizing wait for the blood test results confirmed our worst fears – Rohan was also down with dengue. Suddenly, the stories on NDTV about the rise in dengue cases across Maharashtra felt terrifyingly real.
normalised: News of Mrs. Sharma’s illness spread like wildfire throughout our close-knit community. Soon after, my own son, Rohan, started exhibiting similar symptoms on fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four. A quick trip to the local clinic and another agonizing wait for the blood test results confirmed our worst fears – Rohan was also down with dengue. Suddenly, the stories on N-D-T-V about the rise in dengue cases across Maharashtra felt terrifyingly real.

unnormalised: The local municipal corporation (BMC) finally sprang into action. On 20/07/2024, a team visited our building to conduct a fogging operation. They sprayed insecticide in every corner, targeting potential mosquito breeding grounds. BMC health workers distributed pamphlets educating residents about preventive measures, emphasizing the importance of eliminating stagnant water sources. They advised us to use mosquito repellents with 20% DEET and to wear full-sleeved clothing, especially during dawn and dusk, the peak mosquito biting times.
normalised: The local municipal corporation (B-M-C) finally sprang into action. On twentieth July two thousand and twenty four, a team visited our building to conduct a fogging operation. They sprayed insecticide in every corner, targeting potential mosquito breeding grounds. B-M-C health workers distributed pamphlets educating residents about preventive measures, emphasizing the importance of eliminating stagnant water sources. They advised us to use mosquito repellents with twenty percent D-E-E-T and to wear full-sleeved clothing, especially during dawn and dusk, the peak mosquito biting times.

unnormalised: The experience was a stark reminder of how vulnerable we are to infectious diseases, particularly in densely populated urban areas. The sheer number of cases reported in a single week – roughly 350 new patients at KEM Hospital alone – was alarming. It highlighted the need for better sanitation, improved public health awareness, and more proactive measures by the authorities to prevent outbreaks. The cost of treatment, including diagnostic tests like the ELISA test costing Rs. 1500 at private labs, and medications, can be a significant burden for many families.
normalised: The experience was a stark reminder of how vulnerable we are to infectious diseases, particularly in densely populated urban areas. The sheer number of cases reported in a single week – roughly three hundred and fifty new patients at K-E-M Hospital alone – was alarming. It highlighted the need for better sanitation, improved public health awareness, and more proactive measures by the authorities to prevent outbreaks. The cost of treatment, including diagnostic tests like the E-L-I-S-A test costing rupees one thousand five hundred at private labs, and medications, can be a significant burden for many families.

unnormalised: Thankfully, both Mrs. Sharma and Rohan recovered fully after about 10 days. However, the experience left us all with a heightened sense of awareness and a renewed commitment to taking preventive measures. Now, every Sunday, we make it a point to clean our surroundings, eliminate any standing water, and ensure our mosquito nets are in good condition. The scare served as a valuable, albeit unpleasant, lesson in the importance of community vigilance and proactive healthcare.
